sub_title: NEWAVE Scientific Project Manager | Water Resources Engineer | European Climate Pact Ambassador | Youth Advocate | Capacity Development & Leadership Engagement
summary:
Alway curious and never tired to learn with others. I believe education is key to face our sustainability challenges, to create positive connections and build together a better world. Environmental engineer by training, I strecth my work across different disciplines in the water and environmental sector.

Currently working as Scientific Project Manager at the Institute for Environmental Studies (IVM), Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam, for the EU-funded Marie Curie Innovative Training Network 'NEWAVE' (Next Water Governance). I have been previously working with the International Water Association (IWA) in the members engagement team, crossing multiple units: Water Policy and Regulation; Young Water Professionals; and Strategic Programmes. I have gained experience in projects coordination, implementation and evaluation; networks management and partners engagement; developing and running capacity and professional development programs, conferences and other events, and related communication campaigns. At TU Delft, I worked in numerous research projects focusing on: agriculture and rural development; urban planning; flood risk assessment; water scarcity and drought management; water, environmental, climate policies and governance. 

I am experienced in multidisciplinary team working, collaborating with partners from public, private and non-for-profit sectors. I have been mainly working in Europe (NL, Italy, Spain), with long and short term missions abroad, including Africa (Ghana and Ethiopia), Canada, and China. 

MSc Degree in Civil Engineer, Water Resources Management, from Delft University of Technology (The NL) - complemented by master studies in Cultural Anthropology and Development Sociology at Leiden University as student guest; BSc in Environmental Engineering from University of Rome La Sapienza (Italy) with one year abroad at Granada University (Spain).

treasury_media.title: Taking measurement of the drainage system in Accra, Ghana
treasury_media.description:
Capture of a fieldwork day in Accra, during the Project Flood Risk Accra (see link in the profile). 
Air temperature around 30 degrees Celsius. Real feeling was about 38, yet refreshed by the enthusiasm of carrying out our surveys.

authors.headline: NEWAVE Scientific Project Manager | Water Resources Engineer | European Climate Pact Ambassador | Youth Advocate | Capacity Development & Leadership Engagement

profile_positions.description:
Working in the coordination and implementation of the EU-funded Marie Curie Innovative Training Network 'NEWAVE' (Next Water Governance), and representing the project as European Climate Pact Ambassador.

Main responsibilities include, among others: participation in Network Management Committee (executive board); drafting management plan and project implementation; monitoring progress and evaluation, drafting reports to the European Commission; overseeing annual budget for activities and related admin; curating educational component and organizational aspects, including co-creation of training programme with project members, network events and other initiatives; research involvement at the interface between policy and science; overseeing communication activities through project channels (website, social media, newsletters) and dissemination of the project results; partners engagement and maintenance; representing NEWAVE at international conferences and events.

*About NEWAVE*
NEWAVE is a Marie Skłodowska-Curie Innovative Training Network (ITN) on the ‘Next Water Governance’. The aim of the project is to equip a new generation of future water governance leaders with fundamental knowledge, advanced skills, and adequate tools to address current and future water governance challenges. Latest scientific concepts and methodologies, from fundamental to applied research, are guaranteed thanks to the exceptional and diversified scientific experience of the NEWAVE Consortium, the inter- and trans-disciplinary approach and the prominence of the partner organisations, including some of the most renowned academic institutions, leading international organizations, NGOs and the public and private sector.

More info at the link below | Follow on Twitter @NEWAVE_NETWORK
profile_positions.title: Scientific Project Manager
Strategic Programmes Officer

profile_positions.description:
- Coordination of IWA international network of Young Water Professionals, promoting their engagement, integration and exposure to IWA activities and Specialist Groups. 
- Coordination of the International Young Water Professionals Conference 2019 (June, Toronto Canada), other IWA young water professionals events and workshops.
- Professional development for IWA Young Water Professionals, including the organization of: dialogues with seniors, webinars on career developments, blogs, interviews and videos.
profile_positions.title: Leadership Engagement Officer - Emerging Water Leaders
Internship - Water Policy and Regulation

profile_positions.description:
Professional area: Agriculture, Remote sensing.

Assistant to the Project 'Measuring Plant Thirst', led by Dr. Ir. Susan Steele-Dunne.
The project aimed at monitoring the amount and movement of water in plants by remote sensing (satellite,drones,aircraft), in order to detect when the plants start experiencing water stress. Results would allow to remotely advise irrigation schedules, contributing to water saving measures. 

Job task: Fieldwork research in dutch farms (Flevoland, the NL). Taking crops measurements in pilot areas - soil moisture, plant height, plant stage - to be validated with satellite data.

More info at:
https://www.tudelft.nl/en/ceg/research/stories-of-science/measuring-plant-thirst/
profile_positions.title: Research Assistant, Water Resources Management

profile_positions.description:
Professional area: Agriculture, Water Resources, Environmental-Climate-Agricultural Policies.

Gathering field data for my MSc thesis: "Exploring water scarcity and drought management in agriculture in Sicily. Actors' performance of European policy instruments". 

The research was supervised by TU Delft and European Commission (DG CLIMA), and partially carried out at Palermo University.
The project addressed issues of drought and water scarcity management with an integrated approach from field level to international level. Research methods consisted of:
- qualitative: semi-structured interviews to stakeholders within the water sector; analysis of official documents and scientific literature; direct observations at farms and institutions;
- quantitative: questionnaires to farmers.
During the field research, participation to seminars and public meetings was also carried out (Water Wold Day; Engineers Association Events).

More info at:
http://resolver.tudelft.nl/uuid:9a8eb6d8-37d7-4680-99f3-d32bf9cc6d27
profile_positions.title: Student Researcher, Environmental Engineering

profile_positions.description:
Professional area: Urbanism, Water infrastructures

Assistant to DIMI Special Project ‘Intelligent SUBsurface Quality: Intelligent use of subsurface infrastructure for surface quality’, led by Dr. F.L. Hooimeijer.
Job taks: Technical support and facilitator during workshops.

Delft Deltas, Infrastructures & Mobility Initiative (DIMI) is developing integral solutions for urgent societal problems related to vital infrastructure for water safety and smart mobility, which are intrinsic to the natural and built environment. Challenges faced include: climate change, rising sea levels, economic development and increasing urbanization.
An integral, innovative and down to earth approach, in which different disciplines cooperate, is used to find the best solutions to such issues. 

More info at the link below
profile_positions.title: Assistant Project Officer, Urban water infrastructures

profile_positions.description:
Professional area: Flood risk management.

Prepared and carried out Project Flood Risk Accra. 
Research project to (a) analyze the flood risk and assess the causes of urban flooding in pilot areas in Ghana's Capital Accra, using an innovate and integrated approach (combination of technical and social sciences; use of smartphones to collect data and IT); and to (b) develop a methodology for urban flood risk assessment that can be used for other African cities facing similar issues.

Tasks: Project development and execution; Technical analysis (GIS; Hydrological modeling on SOBEK); qualitative research; involvement of local stakeholders within the project (citizens, NGOs, consultants and local government, dutch embassy). 
Fieldwork research and activities were carried out for two months, under the supervision of dutch consultancies and with the partnership of local students and Research Institutes.
Supervisor: Ir. J. van der Zwet

http://www.floodriskaccra.com/project/
